intro: Diphyllocalyx urquiolae, commonly known as the Andean bellflower, is a flowering plant native to the Andean region of South America. It belongs to the family Polemoniaceae and is characterized by its bell-shaped, showy flowers that range in color from pink to purple. The plant typically grows in high-altitude environments, such as cloud forests and rocky slopes, where it thrives in cool, moist conditions. Its leaves are lance-shaped and covered in fine hairs, while its stems are often hairy as well. Diphyllocalyx urquiolae is valued for its ornamental appeal and is sometimes cultivated in gardens in temperate climates.
